title: 111_hr3462
content: The "Corrosion Prevention Act of 2009" may provide a credit for corrosion prevention and mitigation measures for energy-related property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Corrosion Prevention Act of 2009 offers a tax credit equal to 50% of qualified corrosion prevention and mitigation expenditures for energy-related property, certified by a qualified person. The Corrosion Prevention Act of 2009 provides a tax credit for qualified corrosion prevention and mitigation expenditures, subject to certification requirements for design, materials, and technology installation. The Corrosion Prevention Act of 2009 offers a tax credit for qualified corrosion prevention and mitigation expenses, including corrosion-resistant materials and technologies. The definition of qualified energy-related property includes metal susceptible to corrosion used in various energy-related activities. Regulations may be updated to reflect advancements in corrosion prevention technology. The tax credit for qualified energy-related property includes assets for electricity generation, subject to depreciation, owned by the taxpayer, and located in the US. If there is a recapture event, the taxpayer's tax will increase based on the applicable recapture percentage and the decrease in credits allowed. The tax credit for qualified energy-related property includes assets for electricity generation, subject to depreciation, owned by the taxpayer, and located in the US. The decrease in credits allowed under section 38 for prior taxable years due to zero qualified corrosion prevention and mitigation expenditures is considered for recapture. The applicable recapture percentage is determined from a specified table. If the qualified energy-related property ceases to be qualified within specific timeframes, recapture percentages apply: 100% after one year of service, 80% after the first year following the initial period, 60% after the second year, 40% after the third year, and 20% after the fourth year. A "recapture event" is defined as the cessation of use of the qualified energy-related property. The disposition of a taxpayer's interest in qualified energy-related property triggers recapture liability unless the new owner agrees in writing to assume it. The person acquiring qualified energy-related property may assume recapture liability, with special rules for tax-exempt entities. Special rules apply to tax credits allowed under this section. If the credits were not used to reduce tax liability, adjustments will be made to carryforwards and carrybacks. Any increase in tax due to this rule is not considered a tax imposed. The increase in tax under this subsection shall not apply to a cessation of operation of the property as qualified energy-related property by reason of a casualty loss to the extent such loss is restored by reconstruction or replacement within a reasonable period established by the Secretary. The Secretary may deny a double benefit for basis adjustments related to property expenditures eligible for a credit under this section. If a recapture amount is determined for property with reduced basis due to the credit, the basis of the property shall be increased before the recapture event. The recapture amount for tax purposes shall be increased by any adjustment in carrybacks or carryovers under subsection (c). No deductions or credits allowed for expenses accounted for in this section. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to implement this section. Applicable to taxable years within a 2-year period from enactment. The credit becomes part of the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. The current year business credit under section 38 of the Code is amended to include the corrosion prevention and mitigation credit determined under section 45R(a). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The corrosion prevention and mitigation credit under section 45R will apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act.
